isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 2000 4000 and 8000 MODELS BUILT OCTOBER 1, 1998 AND AFTER - ALLISON 2000 SERIES™ (LCT) TRANSMISSION ELECTRONIC CONTROLS - TROUBLESHOOTING

svcsubsecinfo.para: The troubleshooting charts in this service section focus on the International harnesses and components. The emphasis is determining if the International circuits and components that could cause the condition are functioning properly, and steps needed to correct any such conditions.

If International-related circuits and components are determined to be functioning properly, and the condition is still present, an authorized Allison dealer should continue the troubleshooting process.
The troubleshooting process includes the following:

item.para: Knowing the proper maintenance techniques and practices to prevent damage to the electronic components during the troubleshooting process.
Checking the vehicle for conditions that are not part of the electronic control system for the transmission that could cause the symptom or diagnostic code to be present.
Use of TransPro diagnostic tool to read and understand diagnostic codes that may be present.

Use of Troubleshooting Charts to systematically diagnose the various electrical circuits in an efficient manner. It is often as important to know which circuits are functioning correctly as it is to identify a circuit that is not operating correctly. Refer to the Operation description before diagnosing a circuit. Understanding the circuit is key to proper troubleshooting.

The troubleshooting charts are designed for the technician to use the Fluke 88 Digital Multimeter. If a TransPro diagnostic tool is available, it can be used for certain general systems tests, but the Fluke 88 is still necessary to isolate the defect to a specific area.

When performing electrical checks on the harness connectors, do not insert the test meter probes into the connectors. Use Allison breakout box, part number J 43799, when testing the TCM connectors. Use International breakout box ZTSE-4445 when testing International engine controller connectors. Use jumper wires for testing remaining connectors.

Fabricate jumper wires using the appropriate mating terminal--a short length of wire with an alligator clip on the end without the terminal. Insert the terminal into the connector and attach the meter leads with the alligator clip. For the Allison transmission harness, an Allison Jumper Wiring Kit, part number J39197, is available from authorized Allison dealers.

para.emph: The following must be read and understood before beginning the troubleshooting process.

step1.para: The engine and ignition must always be OFF before disconnecting or connecting any harness connectors. When disconnecting a harness connector, the pulling force must be applied to the connector and not pull the connector loose by pulling on the wires.

If vehicle system power is turned on while a harness is disconnected, diagnostic codes will be registered. After a harness is reconnected to the electronic control system, the computer diagnostics should be ignored and cleared from memory.
Inspect all related connectors for damage. They may have damaged pins, loose wires or terminals or may have lost the necessary spring to maintain proper connections.

If the pins or sockets of the electronic control harness connections are dirty or corroded, they should be cleaned using a good quality, non-residue, non-lubricating cleaning solvent that does not contain petroleum distillates. The solvent should not conduct electricity (will cause shorting between terminals) and should evaporate quickly, eliminating the possibility of condensation within the connectors. ALWAYS remove any excess solvent before assembling a connector to its mating component. Solvents trapped in a connector can damage the connector sealing capabilities.
Check transmission OIL LEVEL and ensure correct oil level. Improper oil level can create conditions which cause diagnostic codes to be registered.
Check battery state-of-charge. To perform diagnostics, the batteries must be fully charged. Refer to GROUP 08 - BATTERIES in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for procedure to check batteries.
